item.title: Why Estimation Theory
item.description: In statistics, we work with samples. For example, the sample mean is easily calculated. However, it is the population mean that is more valuable. Suppose we have one sample $S_i$, which is used to calculate the mean of the sample $\mu_i$. We have two key problems to solve at this moment. Can we use this sample mean $\mu_i$ to represent the population mean $\mu_p$? How good is our estimations? To answer these questions, we need to work out the properties of the samples themselves and work out a theory to instruct us to infer population statistics from sample statistics.

item.title: Confidence Interval
item.description: We will use upper cases for the abstract variable and lower cases for the actual numbers. Why is Confidence Interval Needed? Suppose I sample the population multiple times, the mean value $\mu_i$ of the sample is calculated for each sample. It is a good question to ask how different these $\mu_i$ are compared to the true mean $\mu_p$ of the population. In this article, we would need to specify several notations. $X$ is the quantity we are measuring. $\bar X$ is the mean of the quantity $X$. item.description: Conformal prediction is a method to predict a consistent confidence interval in an on-line setting. on-line An on-line setting is to predict continuously for sequentially incoming data points.
